data.title: Timberwolves trade Al Jefferson to Utah Jazz for two first-round draft picks
data.meta_description: There has been a definite push in the offseason to make the Timberwolves more athletic and versatile along the front line — and Al Jefferson did not fit the profile for the team’s projected new look. The Wolves sent Jefferson’s methodic, low-post game to the Utah Jazz on Tuesday in exchange for two future first-round […]
data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

There has been a definite push in the offseason to make the Timberwolves more athletic and versatile along the front line — and Al Jefferson did not fit the profile for the team’s projected new look.

The Wolves sent Jefferson’s methodic, low-post game to the Utah Jazz on Tuesday in exchange for two future first-round draft picks and 7-foot center Kosta Koufos, a seldom-used backup who might not find an opening on the Wolves’ revamped roster.

Needing a power forward to replace free agent Carlos Boozer, who went to the Chicago Bulls in a sign-and-trade deal, the Jazz were willing to take on the remaining three years of Jefferson’s contract, worth $42 million, and help the Wolves embark on a new direction.

“We both came to the conclusion that the time was right to do this,” Wolves president of basketball operations David Kahn said of a meeting he had in May with Jefferson and his agent, Jeff Schwartz. “With the players we have coming in, there wouldn’t be enough playing time for everybody. We did a fair deal for Al and us.”

Sweetening the deal for Utah is the traded player exception the club gets from the NBA, a provision that allows the Jazz to absorb Jefferson’s $13 million salary next season despite being over the salary cap.

Saying goodbye to Jefferson, the Wolves’ leading scorer last season (17.1 points) and No. 2 rebounder (9.3), cuts the last link to the Kevin Garnett trade in 2007 that former Wolves general manager Kevin McHale negotiated with the Boston Celtics.

Jefferson, 25, was the last remaining player of the five former Celtics who came to Minnesota in a deal that generated dramatic change for the franchise. The other four — Ryan Gomes, Sebastian Telfair, Theo Ratliff and Gerald Green — have moved on. Jefferson and Gomes had the longest tenures with the Wolves, surviving three losing seasons.

“Al recognized it might be a couple more years before we contend,” Kahn said. “He wants to win, and I understood where he was coming from.”

As the key component in the Garnett deal, which also gave the Wolves two first-round picks, there was hope that Jefferson would establish himself in Minnesota, particularly after the 6-foot-10 center-forward averaged 21.0 points and 11.3 rebounds in his first season with the Wolves. But coaching changes, injuries and personal problems kept the six-year veteran from building on his impressive start with the Wolves.

Jefferson’s productivity dropped last season after he struggled to recover from major surgery on his left knee that kept him out of the final 32 games of the 2008-09 season. He suffered a torn anterior cruciate ligament and battled Achilles’ tendinitis at the start of last season. Jefferson missed two games in November because of the death of his grandmother and two in April because of a family member’s illness.

The low point of the season for Jefferson came in the early-morning hours of Feb. 28 when he was arrested for driving under the influence near downtown Minneapolis. Jefferson pleaded guilty to the fourth-degree misdemeanor. He was fined $300 and sentenced to two years’ probation and 40 hours of community service. The Wolves suspended Jefferson for two games without pay.

In addition to the off-court troubles, Jefferson spent most of the season trying to adapt to coach Kurt Rambis’ triangle offense. Rambis was Jefferson’s third coach in his three-season run with the Wolves. Jefferson also played for McHale and Randy Wittman.

Jefferson became expendable when the Wolves re-signed free-agent center Darko Milicic. Before the June 24 draft, Kahn indicated that if the Serbia-Montenegro native re-signed with the Wolves, he would look into trading Jefferson, who had been the subject of trade rumors since January. The Wolves also signed Serbian native Nikola Pekovic and acquired two-year veteran Michael Beasley from Miami to help revitalize a front line that returns Kevin Love.

The upgraded front line led Kahn to tell Koufos’ agent that he would consider trading him “if the opportunity presented itself.” Koufos, a first-round pick of Utah from Ohio State in 2008, appeared in only 36 games last season, averaging 1.5 points and 1.3 rebounds.

Kahn said he had “nothing to report” on the possibility of Milwaukee free-agent point guard Luke Ridnour joining the Wolves. Reports surfaced that the Wolves were prepared to offer Ridnour a four-year deal worth $16 million.

Originally Published: July 12, 2010 at 11:01 p.m.
